content.heading: C++ Data Types
paragraphs:
As explained in the Variables chapter, a variable in C++ must be a specified data type. 
Data types dictate the kind of data a variable can hold, which in turn affects the operations that can be performed on that variable.
C++ provides several built-in data types, which can be classified into basic data types, derived data types, and user-defined data types.

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
int myNum = 5;  // Integer (whole number)
float myFloatNum = 5.99;  // Floating point number

double myDoubleNum = 9.98;  // Floating point number
char myLetter = 'D';  // Character

bool myBoolean = true;  // Boolean
string myText = "Hello";  // String

content.heading: Basic Data Types
paragraphs:
The data type specifies the size and type of information the variable will store:

1. int: Used for storing integers (whole numbers).
2. float: Used for storing single-precision floating point numbers.
3. double: Used for storing double-precision floating point numbers.
4. char: Used for storing single characters.
5. bool: Used for storing boolean values (true or false).
6. string: Used for storing a sequence of characters (text).
